Which of the following events occurs first when an action potential reaches the presynaptic terminal of the neuromuscular junction?

options.label: A
options.text: Release of acetylcholine (ACh) from the ACh vesicles

options.label: B
options.text: Opening of calcium channels

options.label: C
options.text: Release of acetylcholinesterase into the synaptic cleft

options.label: D
options.text: Increased influx of sodium ions

questions.correct_answer: B. Opening of calcium channels
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Opening of calcium channels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Incorrect. The release of acetylcholine from its vesicles into the synaptic cleft is a critical step in neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction , but it occurs after the initial opening of voltage-gated calcium channels triggered by the action potential .

  • • acetylcholine
  • • synaptic cleft
  • • critical step
  • • neurotransmission
  • • neuromuscular junction
  • • after
  • • initial opening
  • • voltage-gated calcium channels
  • • action potential
  • • Option C: Incorrect. Acetylcholinesterase , which breaks down acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft , is already present in the synaptic cleft before the action potential arrives . Its activity is not directly triggered by the action potential but is essential for terminating the signal.
  • • Option C:
  • • Acetylcholinesterase
  • • breaks down acetylcholine
  • • synaptic cleft
  • • present
  • • synaptic cleft before
  • • action potential arrives
  • • Option D: Incorrect. While the action potential propagation involves the influx of sodium ions through voltage-gated sodium channels , at the presynaptic terminal of the neuromuscular junction , the initial direct response to the action potential is the opening of calcium channels , not an influx of sodium ions.
  • • Option D:
  • • action potential propagation involves

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels is the first event at the presynaptic terminal following the arrival of an action potential , leading to the release of acetylcholine and muscle contraction .

questions.text: A 43-year-old professional pianist visits the clinic with complaints of decreased precision and strength in his finger movements, particularly during complex musical pieces. The neurologist discusses the concept of motor units and their role in fine motor skills. Which of the following best describes a motor unit in the context of muscle innervation?

options.label: A
options.text: Multiple motor nerve fibers innervating a single muscle

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple motor nerve fibers innervating multiple muscle fibers

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.correct_answer: C. Multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Incorrect. A motor unit consists not of multiple motor nerve fibers innervating a single muscle but of a single motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Incorrect. While multiple motor nerve fibers can innervate multiple muscle fibers , this does not define a motor unit. A motor unit specifically refers to the muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve fiber .
  • • Option B:
  • • multiple motor nerve fibers
  • • innervate
  • • multiple muscle fibers
  • • refers
  • • muscle fibers
  • • innervated
  • • single motor nerve fiber
  • • Option D: Incorrect. The definition of a motor unit is accurately described as multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve , making option C correct.
  • • Option D:
  • • single motor nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that a motor unit comprises multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor neuron , which is crucial for understanding muscle coordination and fine motor control .

questions.text: A 25-year-old professional weightlifter experiences a sudden sharp pain in his biceps during a heavy lift. Concerned about a potential muscle tear, he consults a sports medicine physician. The physician explains the mechanics of muscle contraction, focusing on the power stroke within the sarcomere. Which of the following statements accurately describes the power stroke in skeletal muscle contraction?

options.label: A
options.text: Actin binding sites are exposed, allowing myosin to bind.

options.label: B
options.text: The myosin head moves towards its neck, pulling the actin filament.

options.label: C
options.text: Myosin head binds to the actin site, initiating the contraction cycle.

options.label: D
options.text: The myosin head slides over the actin filament without detachment.

questions.correct_answer: B. The myosin head moves towards its neck, pulling the actin filament.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The myosin head moves towards its neck, pulling the actin filament.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Incorrect. While the exposure of actin binding sites is a prerequisite for the power stroke , it is not a description of the power stroke itself. This exposure allows myosin heads to bind to actin , setting the stage for the power stroke .
  • • Option A:
  • • exposure
  • • actin binding sites
  • • prerequisite
  • • power stroke
  • • allows myosin
  • • heads
  • • bind to actin
  • • stage
  • • power stroke
  • • Option C: Incorrect. The binding of the myosin head to the actin site is the initial step that precedes the power stroke. The power stroke itself involves the movement of the myosin head after binding to actin , not the binding event.
  • • Option C:
  • • power stroke
  • • movement
  • • myosin head
  • • after
  • • actin
  • • Option D: Incorrect. The power stroke involves the pivoting of the myosin head while it is attached to actin , pulling the actin filament . The myosin head does not slide over actin; rather, it detaches and reattaches to a new site on the actin filament for subsequent cycles.
  • • Option D:
  • • pivoting
  • • myosin head
  • • attached
  • • actin
  • • pulling
  • • actin filament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the power stroke in skeletal muscle contraction as the movement of the myosin head towards its neck region , pulling the actin filament and generating muscle tension .

questions.text: A 30-year-old marathon runner presents to the clinic with questions about recovery strategies following intense training sessions. She's particularly interested in understanding the concept of "oxygen debt" and how it affects her post-exercise recovery. Which of the following statements about exercise-induced oxygen debt is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Stored oxygen can be used for aerobic metabolism during intense exercise.

options.label: B
options.text: Anaerobic cellular respiration occurs during periods of intense exercise when oxygen supply is insufficient.

options.label: C
options.text: The phosphagen system needs to be reconstituted post-exercise, contributing to oxygen debt.

options.label: D
options.text: Approximately 7 liters of oxygen are required to repay the oxygen debt incurred during intense exercise.

questions.correct_answer: D. Approximately 7 liters of oxygen are required to repay the oxygen debt incurred during intense exercise.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Approximately 7 liters of oxygen are required to repay the oxygen debt incurred during intense exercise.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Incorrect. While muscles do store some oxygen bound to myoglobin , the quantity is much less than 2 liters and is quickly depleted during intense exercise , leading to anaerobic metabolism .

  • • intense exercise
  • • anaerobic metabolism
  • • Option B: Correct statement. During high-intensity exercise , when oxygen demand exceeds supply , muscles rely on anaerobic respiration to generate ATP , contributing to the accumulation of lactate and the development of oxygen debt .

  • • oxygen
  • • demand
  • • exceeds supply
  • • anaerobic respiration
  • • ATP
  • • accumulation
  • • lactate
  • • development
  • • oxygen debt
  • • Option C: Correct statement. Post-exercise , the phosphagen system ( ATP and creatine phosphate ) must be replenished using aerobic metabolism , which contributes to the oxygen debt.
